newsitem.title: RUSSIA: De Beers says Russia talks positive, no deal yet.
newsitem.headline: De Beers says Russia talks positive, no deal yet.

text.p: Russia and De Beers have yet to reach a final agreement in their latest round of talks on a new three-year diamond deal but a De Beers official said that negotiations had been positive.

Raymond Clarke, head of De Beers' Moscow representation, declined to say when an agreement might be reached with Almazy Rossii-Sakha (ARS, or Diamonds of Russia-Sakha), which is Russia's largest diamond producer and sole authorised exporter.
"I really can't speculate on when an agreement will be signed," Clarke said, after a day of talks.
It was not clear whether talks would continue on Thursday.
"Things are proceeding along the lines of the memorandum of understanding," Clarke said. "I can tell you that we've had a very useful, positive couple of days."
De Beers Consolidated Mines Ltd signed a memorandum with the Russian government in February under which it will take half of Russia's rough diamond output.
But a formal agreement between the South African group and ARS has yet to be reached.
Clarke did not comment on an Itar-Tass news agency report that Russia's new industry ministry had named a former diamond official to head its department for precious metals and stones.
Tass quoted sources in the recently-formed ministry as saying Vladimir Piskunov, formerly a vice-president of ARS, had been appointed department chief.
Under its previous agreement with De Beers, Russia had to sell 75 percent of its stones through De Beers's Central Selling Organisation.
